subject: Re: [junit] Re: accessing JUnit runner/suite objects at runtime (or... rule for a suite)
msgSnippet: Ah, I meant a custom suite runner.  Here s something you could do: @IncludeCategory(FailingTests.class) @RunWith(MyCategories.class)
messageBody:
Ah, I meant a custom suite runner. Here's something you could do:

@IncludeCategory(FailingTests.class)
@RunWith(MyCategories.class)
@SuiteClasses(AllTests.class)
public class FailingTests {
public static class MyCategories extends Categories {
public MyCategories(Class<?> klass, final RunnerBuilder builder)
throws InitializationError {
super(klass, new RunnerBuilder() {
public Runner runnerForClass(Class<?> testClass) throws Throwable {
if (somethingIsWrongWithYourAnnotations(testClass))
throw InitializationError("Fix your annotations!");
else
return builder.runnerForClass(testClass);
}
});
}
}
}

It could be prettier, but this should work.

David Saff

On Tue, Jan 25, 2011 at 3:02 PM, sdrothco <steve.roth@...> wrote:
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>>
>> Steve,
>>
>> Do you have a custom Suite class?  You could use that to loop through
>> the included test cases and validate each one.
>>
>>    David Saff
>
> Yes, I have a custom Suite class.  That approach sounds great.
>
> But how can I access the test cases within the suite?
>
>
> This is my Suite class:
>
> /**
>  * Test suite to run all tests annotated with
>  * @Category(FailingTests.class)
>  */
> @IncludeCategory(FailingTests.class)
> @RunWith(Categories.class)
> @SuiteClasses(AllTests.class)
> public class FailingTests { }
>
> and the AllTests Suite is:
>
> @RunWith(ClasspathSuite.class)
> public class AllTests { }
